BitField.name: READ_ERROR

BitField.description: If 1, the channel received a write bus error. Write one to clear.\n WRITE_ADDR shows the approximate address where the bus error was encountered (will not to be earlier, or more than 5 transfers later)
BitField.name: WRITE_ERROR

BitField.description: This flag goes high when the channel starts a new transfer sequence, and low when the last transfer of that sequence completes. Clearing EN while BUSY is high pauses the channel, and BUSY will stay high while paused.\n\n To terminate a sequence early (and clear the BUSY flag), see CHAN_ABORT.
BitField.name: BUSY

BitField.description: If 1, this channel's data transfers are visible to the sniff hardware, and each transfer will advance the state of the checksum. This only applies if the sniff hardware is enabled, and has this channel selected.\n\n This allows checksum to be enabled or disabled on a per-control- block basis.
BitField.name: SNIFF_EN

BitField.description: Apply byte-swap transformation to DMA data.\n For byte data, this has no effect. For halfword data, the two bytes of each halfword are swapped. For word data, the four bytes of each word are swapped to reverse order.
BitField.name: BSWAP

BitField.description: In QUIET mode, the channel does not generate IRQs at the end of every transfer block. Instead, an IRQ is raised when NULL is written to a trigger register, indicating the end of a control block chain.\n\n This reduces the number of interrupts to be serviced by the CPU when transferring a DMA chain of many small control blocks.
BitField.name: IRQ_QUIET

BitField.description: Select a Transfer Request signal.\n The channel uses the transfer request signal to pace its data transfer rate. Sources for TREQ signals are internal (TIMERS) or external (DREQ, a Data Request from the system).\n 0x0 to 0x3a -> select DREQ n as TREQ
BitField.name: TREQ_SEL

BitField.description: When this channel completes, it will trigger the channel indicated by CHAIN_TO. Disable by setting CHAIN_TO = _(this channel)_.\n Reset value is equal to channel number (9).
BitField.name: CHAIN_TO

BitField.description: Select whether RING_SIZE applies to read or write addresses.\n If 0, read addresses are wrapped on a (1 << RING_SIZE) boundary. If 1, write addresses are wrapped.
BitField.name: RING_SEL

BitField.description: Size of address wrap region. If 0, don't wrap. For values n > 0, only the lower n bits of the address will change. This wraps the address on a (1 << n) byte boundary, facilitating access to naturally-aligned ring buffers.\n\n Ring sizes between 2 and 32768 bytes are possible. This can apply to either read or write addresses, based on value of RING_SEL.
BitField.name: RING_SIZE

BitField.description: If 1, the write address increments with each transfer. If 0, each write is directed to the same, initial address.\n\n Generally this should be disabled for memory-to-peripheral transfers.
BitField.name: INCR_WRITE

BitField.description: If 1, the read address increments with each transfer. If 0, each read is directed to the same, initial address.\n\n Generally this should be disabled for peripheral-to-memory transfers.
BitField.name: INCR_READ

BitField.description: Set the size of each bus transfer (byte/halfword/word). READ_ADDR and WRITE_ADDR advance by this amount (1/2/4 bytes) with each transfer.
BitField.name: DATA_SIZE

BitField.description: HIGH_PRIORITY gives a channel preferential treatment in issue scheduling: in each scheduling round, all high priority channels are considered first, and then only a single low priority channel, before returning to the high priority channels.\n\n This only affects the order in which the DMA schedules channels. The DMA's bus priority is not changed. If the DMA is not saturated then a low priority channel will see no loss of throughput.
BitField.name: HIGH_PRIORITY

BitField.description: DMA Channel Enable.\n When 1, the channel will respond to triggering events, which will cause it to become BUSY and start transferring data. When 0, the channel will ignore triggers, stop issuing transfers, and pause the current transfer sequence (i.e. BUSY will remain high if already high)
BitField.name: EN

Register.description: Alias for channel 9 CTRL register
Register.name: CH9_AL1_CTRL

Register.description: Alias for channel 9 READ_ADDR register
Register.name: CH9_AL1_READ_ADDR

Register.description: Alias for channel 9 WRITE_ADDR register
Register.name: CH9_AL1_WRITE_ADDR

Register.description: Alias for channel 9 TRANS_COUNT register\n This is a trigger register (0xc). Writing a nonzero value will\n reload the channel counter and start the channel.
Register.name: CH9_AL1_TRANS_COUNT_TRIG

Register.name: CH9_AL2_CTRL

Register.name: CH9_AL2_WRITE_ADDR_TRIG

Register.name: CH9_AL3_CTRL

Register.description: Alias for channel 9 WRITE_ADDR register
Register.name: CH9_AL3_WRITE_ADDR

Register.description: Alias for channel 9 TRANS_COUNT register
Register.name: CH9_AL3_TRANS_COUNT

Register.description: Alias for channel 9 READ_ADDR register\n This is a trigger register (0xc). Writing a nonzero value will\n reload the channel counter and start the channel.
Register.name: CH9_AL3_READ_ADDR_TRIG

Register.description: DMA Channel 10 Read Address pointer\n This register updates automatically each time a read completes. The current value is the next address to be read by this channel.
Register.name: CH10_READ_ADDR

Register.description: DMA Channel 10 Write Address pointer\n This register updates automatically each time a write completes. The current value is the next address to be written by this channel.
Register.name: CH10_WRITE_ADDR

Register.description:
DMA Channel 10 Transfer Count
 Program the number of bus transfers a channel will perform before halting. Note that, if transfers are larger than one byte in size, this is not equal to the number of bytes transferred (see CTRL_DATA_SIZE).

 When the channel is active, reading this register shows the number of transfers remaining, updating automatically each time a write transfer completes.

 Writing this register sets the RELOAD value for the transfer counter. Each time this channel is triggered, the RELOAD value is copied into the live transfer counter. The channel can be started multiple times, and will perform the same number of transfers each time, as programmed by most recent write.

 The RELOAD value can be observed at CHx_DBG_TCR. If TRANS_COUNT is used as a trigger, the written value is used immediately as the length of the new transfer sequence, as well as being written to RELOAD.
Register.name: CH10_TRANS_COUNT

Register.description: DMA Channel 10 Control and Status
Register.name: CH10_CTRL_TRIG

BitField.description: Logical OR of the READ_ERROR and WRITE_ERROR flags. The channel halts when it encounters any bus error, and always raises its channel IRQ flag.
BitField.name: AHB_ERROR

BitField.description: If 1, the channel received a read bus error. Write one to clear.\n READ_ADDR shows the approximate address where the bus error was encountered (will not to be earlier, or more than 3 transfers later)
BitField.name: READ_ERROR

BitField.description: If 1, the channel received a write bus error. Write one to clear.\n WRITE_ADDR shows the approximate address where the bus error was encountered (will not to be earlier, or more than 5 transfers later)
BitField.name: WRITE_ERROR

BitField.name: TREQ_SEL

Register.description: Interrupt Status (raw)
Register.name: INTR

BitField.description:
Raw interrupt status for DMA Channels 0..15. Bit n corresponds to channel n. Ignores any masking or forcing. Channel interrupts can be cleared by writing a bit mask to INTR, INTS0 or INTS1.

 Channel interrupts can be routed to either of two system-level IRQs based on INTE0 and INTE1.

 This can be used vector different channel interrupts to different ISRs: this might be done to allow NVIC IRQ preemption for more time-critical channels, or to spread IRQ load across different cores.

 It is also valid to ignore this behaviour and just use INTE0/INTS0/IRQ 0.
BitField.name: INTR

Register.description: Interrupt Enables for IRQ 0
Register.name: INTE0

BitField.description: Set bit n to pass interrupts from channel n to DMA IRQ 0.
BitField.name: INTE0

Register.description: Force Interrupts
Register.name: INTF0

BitField.description: Write 1s to force the corresponding bits in INTE0. The interrupt remains asserted until INTF0 is cleared.
BitField.name: INTF0

Register.description: Interrupt Status for IRQ 0
Register.name: INTS0

BitField.description: Indicates active channel interrupt requests which are currently causing IRQ 0 to be asserted.\n Channel interrupts can be cleared by writing a bit mask here.
BitField.name: INTS0

Register.description: Interrupt Enables for IRQ 1
Register.name: INTE1

BitField.description: Set bit n to pass interrupts from channel n to DMA IRQ 1.
BitField.name: INTE1

Register.description: Force Interrupts for IRQ 1
Register.name: INTF1

BitField.description: Write 1s to force the corresponding bits in INTE0. The interrupt remains asserted until INTF0 is cleared.
BitField.name: INTF1

Register.description: Interrupt Status (masked) for IRQ 1
Register.name: INTS1

BitField.description: Indicates active channel interrupt requests which are currently causing IRQ 1 to be asserted.\n Channel interrupts can be cleared by writing a bit mask here.
BitField.name: INTS1

Register.description: Pacing (X/Y) Fractional Timer\n The pacing timer produces TREQ assertions at a rate set by ((X/Y) * sys_clk). This equation is evaluated every sys_clk cycles and therefore can only generate TREQs at a rate of 1 per sys_clk (i.e. permanent TREQ) or less.
Register.name: TIMER0

BitField.description: Pacing Timer Dividend. Specifies the X value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.
BitField.name: X

BitField.description: Pacing Timer Divisor. Specifies the Y value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.
BitField.name: Y

Register.description: Pacing (X/Y) Fractional Timer\n The pacing timer produces TREQ assertions at a rate set by ((X/Y) * sys_clk). This equation is evaluated every sys_clk cycles and therefore can only generate TREQs at a rate of 1 per sys_clk (i.e. permanent TREQ) or less.
Register.name: TIMER1

BitField.description: Pacing Timer Dividend. Specifies the X value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.
BitField.name: X

BitField.description: Pacing Timer Divisor. Specifies the Y value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.
BitField.name: Y

Register.description: Pacing (X/Y) Fractional Timer\n The pacing timer produces TREQ assertions at a rate set by ((X/Y) * sys_clk). This equation is evaluated every sys_clk cycles and therefore can only generate TREQs at a rate of 1 per sys_clk (i.e. permanent TREQ) or less.
Register.name: TIMER2

BitField.description: Pacing Timer Dividend. Specifies the X value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.
BitField.name: X

BitField.description: Pacing Timer Divisor. Specifies the Y value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.
BitField.name: Y

Register.description: Pacing (X/Y) Fractional Timer\n The pacing timer produces TREQ assertions at a rate set by ((X/Y) * sys_clk). This equation is evaluated every sys_clk cycles and therefore can only generate TREQs at a rate of 1 per sys_clk (i.e. permanent TREQ) or less.
Register.name: TIMER3

BitField.description: Pacing Timer Dividend. Specifies the X value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.
BitField.name: X

BitField.description: Pacing Timer Divisor. Specifies the Y value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.
BitField.name: Y

Register.description: Trigger one or more channels simultaneously
Register.name: MULTI_CHAN_TRIGGER

BitField.description: Each bit in this register corresponds to a DMA channel. Writing a 1 to the relevant bit is the same as writing to that channel's trigger register; the channel will start if it is currently enabled and not already busy.
BitField.name: MULTI_CHAN_TRIGGER

Register.description: Sniffer Control
Register.name: SNIFF_CTRL

BitField.description: If set, the result appears inverted (bitwise complement) when read. This does not affect the way the checksum is calculated; the result is transformed on-the-fly between the result register and the bus.
BitField.name: OUT_INV

BitField.description: If set, the result appears bit-reversed when read. This does not affect the way the checksum is calculated; the result is transformed on-the-fly between the result register and the bus.
BitField.name: OUT_REV

BitField.description: Locally perform a byte reverse on the sniffed data, before feeding into checksum.\n\n Note that the sniff hardware is downstream of the DMA channel byteswap performed in the read master: if channel CTRL_BSWAP and SNIFF_CTRL_BSWAP are both enabled, their effects cancel from the sniffer's point of view.
BitField.name: BSWAP

Enum.description: Calculate a CRC-32 (IEEE802.3 polynomial) with bit reversed data
Enum.name: CRC32R

Enum.description: Calculate a CRC-16-CCITT with bit reversed data
Enum.name: CRC16R

Enum.description: XOR reduction over all data. == 1 if the total 1 population count is odd.
Enum.name: EVEN

Enum.description: Calculate a simple 32-bit checksum (addition with a 32 bit accumulator)
Enum.name: SUM

BitField.description: DMA channel for Sniffer to observe
BitField.name: DMACH

BitField.description: Enable sniffer
BitField.name: EN

Register.description: Data accumulator for sniff hardware\n Write an initial seed value here before starting a DMA transfer on the channel indicated by SNIFF_CTRL_DMACH. The hardware will update this register each time it observes a read from the indicated channel. Once the channel completes, the final result can be read from this register.
Register.name: SNIFF_DATA

Register.description: Debug RAF, WAF, TDF levels
Register.name: FIFO_LEVELS

BitField.description: Current Read-Address-FIFO fill level
BitField.name: RAF_LVL

BitField.description: Current Write-Address-FIFO fill level
BitField.name: WAF_LVL

BitField.description: Current Transfer-Data-FIFO fill level
BitField.name: TDF_LVL

Register.description: Abort an in-progress transfer sequence on one or more channels
Register.name: CHAN_ABORT

BitField.description: Each bit corresponds to a channel. Writing a 1 aborts whatever transfer sequence is in progress on that channel. The bit will remain high until any in-flight transfers have been flushed through the address and data FIFOs.\n\n After writing, this register must be polled until it returns all-zero. Until this point, it is unsafe to restart the channel.
BitField.name: CHAN_ABORT

Register.description: The number of channels this DMA instance is equipped with. This DMA supports up to 16 hardware channels, but can be configured with as few as one, to minimise silicon area.
Register.name: N_CHANNELS

Register.description: Read: get channel DREQ counter (i.e. how many accesses the DMA expects it can perform on the peripheral without overflow/underflow. Write any value: clears the counter, and cause channel to re-initiate DREQ handshake.
Register.name: CH0_DBG_CTDREQ

Register.description: Read to get channel TRANS_COUNT reload value, i.e. the length of the next transfer
Register.name: CH0_DBG_TCR

Register.description: Read: get channel DREQ counter (i.e. how many accesses the DMA expects it can perform on the peripheral without overflow/underflow. Write any value: clears the counter, and cause channel to re-initiate DREQ handshake.
Register.name: CH1_DBG_CTDREQ

Register.description: Read to get channel TRANS_COUNT reload value, i.e. the length of the next transfer
Register.name: CH1_DBG_TCR

Register.description: Read: get channel DREQ counter (i.e. how many accesses the DMA expects it can perform on the peripheral without overflow/underflow. Write any value: clears the counter, and cause channel to re-initiate DREQ handshake.
Register.name: CH2_DBG_CTDREQ

Register.description: Read to get channel TRANS_COUNT reload value, i.e. the length of the next transfer
Register.name: CH2_DBG_TCR

Register.description: Read: get channel DREQ counter (i.e. how many accesses the DMA expects it can perform on the peripheral without overflow/underflow. Write any value: clears the counter, and cause channel to re-initiate DREQ handshake.
Register.name: CH3_DBG_CTDREQ

Register.description: Read to get channel TRANS_COUNT reload value, i.e. the length of the next transfer
Register.name: CH3_DBG_TCR

Register.description: Read: get channel DREQ counter (i.e. how many accesses the DMA expects it can perform on the peripheral without overflow/underflow. Write any value: clears the counter, and cause channel to re-initiate DREQ handshake.
Register.name: CH4_DBG_CTDREQ

Register.description: Read to get channel TRANS_COUNT reload value, i.e. the length of the next transfer
Register.name: CH4_DBG_TCR

Register.description: Main control register
Register.name: MAIN_CTRL

BitField.description: Reduced timings for simulation
BitField.name: SIM_TIMING

BitField.description: Device mode = 0, Host mode = 1
BitField.name: HOST_NDEVICE

BitField.description: Enable controller
BitField.name: CONTROLLER_EN

Register.description: Set the SOF (Start of Frame) frame number in the host controller. The SOF packet is sent every 1ms and the host will increment the frame number by 1 each time.
Register.name: SOF_WR

Register.description: Read the last SOF (Start of Frame) frame number seen. In device mode the last SOF received from the host. In host mode the last SOF sent by the host.
Register.name: SOF_RD

Register.description: SIE control register
Register.name: SIE_CTRL

BitField.description: Device: Set bit in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK when EP0 sends a STALL
BitField.name: EP0_INT_STALL

BitField.description: Device: EP0 single buffered = 0, double buffered = 1
BitField.name: EP0_DOUBLE_BUF

BitField.description: Device: Set bit in BUFF_STATUS for every buffer completed on EP0
BitField.name: EP0_INT_1BUF

BitField.description: Device: Set bit in BUFF_STATUS for every 2 buffers completed on EP0
BitField.name: EP0_INT_2BUF

BitField.description: Device: Set bit in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK when EP0 sends a NAK
BitField.name: EP0_INT_NAK

BitField.description: Direct bus drive enable
BitField.name: DIRECT_EN

BitField.description: Direct control of DP
BitField.name: DIRECT_DP

BitField.description: Direct control of DM
BitField.name: DIRECT_DM

BitField.description: Power down bus transceiver
BitField.name: TRANSCEIVER_PD

BitField.description: Device: Pull-up strength (0=1K2, 1=2k3)
BitField.name: RPU_OPT

BitField.description: Device: Enable pull up resistor
BitField.name: PULLUP_EN

BitField.description: Host: Enable pull down resistors
BitField.name: PULLDOWN_EN

BitField.description: Host: Reset bus
BitField.name: RESET_BUS

BitField.description: Device: Remote wakeup. Device can initiate its own resume after suspend.
BitField.name: RESUME

BitField.description: Host: Enable VBUS
BitField.name: VBUS_EN

BitField.description: Host: Enable keep alive packet (for low speed bus)
BitField.name: KEEP_ALIVE_EN

BitField.description: Host: Enable SOF generation (for full speed bus)
BitField.name: SOF_EN

BitField.description: Host: Delay packet(s) until after SOF
BitField.name: SOF_SYNC

BitField.description: Host: Preable enable for LS device on FS hub
BitField.name: PREAMBLE_EN

BitField.description: Host: Stop transaction
BitField.name: STOP_TRANS

BitField.description: Host: Receive transaction (IN to host)
BitField.name: RECEIVE_DATA

BitField.description: Host: Send transaction (OUT from host)
BitField.name: SEND_DATA

BitField.description: Host: Send Setup packet
BitField.name: SEND_SETUP

BitField.description: Host: Start transaction
BitField.name: START_TRANS

Register.description: SIE status register
Register.name: SIE_STATUS

BitField.description:
Data Sequence Error.

 The device can raise a sequence error in the following conditions:

 * A SETUP packet is received followed by a DATA1 packet (data phase should always be DATA0) * An OUT packet is received from the host but doesn't match the data pid in the buffer control register read from DPSRAM

 The host can raise a data sequence error in the following conditions:

 * An IN packet from the device has the wrong data PID
BitField.name: DATA_SEQ_ERROR

BitField.description: ACK received. Raised by both host and device.
BitField.name: ACK_REC

BitField.description: Host: STALL received
BitField.name: STALL_REC

BitField.description: Host: NAK received
BitField.name: NAK_REC

BitField.description: RX timeout is raised by both the host and device if an ACK is not received in the maximum time specified by the USB spec.
BitField.name: RX_TIMEOUT

BitField.description: RX overflow is raised by the Serial RX engine if the incoming data is too fast.
BitField.name: RX_OVERFLOW

BitField.description: Bit Stuff Error. Raised by the Serial RX engine.
BitField.name: BIT_STUFF_ERROR

BitField.description: CRC Error. Raised by the Serial RX engine.
BitField.name: CRC_ERROR

BitField.description: Device: bus reset received
BitField.name: BUS_RESET

BitField.description:
Transaction complete.

 Raised by device if:

 * An IN or OUT packet is sent with the `LAST_BUFF` bit set in the buffer control register

 Raised by host if:

 * A setup packet is sent when no data in or data out transaction follows * An IN packet is received and the `LAST_BUFF` bit is set in the buffer control register * An IN packet is received with zero length * An OUT packet is sent and the `LAST_BUFF` bit is set
BitField.name: TRANS_COMPLETE

BitField.description: Device: Setup packet received
BitField.name: SETUP_REC

BitField.description: Device: connected
BitField.name: CONNECTED

BitField.description: Host: Device has initiated a remote resume. Device: host has initiated a resume.
BitField.name: RESUME

BitField.description: VBUS over current detected
BitField.name: VBUS_OVER_CURR

BitField.description: Host: device speed. Disconnected = 00, LS = 01, FS = 10
BitField.name: SPEED

BitField.description: Bus in suspended state. Valid for device and host. Host and device will go into suspend if neither Keep Alive / SOF frames are enabled.
BitField.name: SUSPENDED

BitField.description: USB bus line state
BitField.name: LINE_STATE

BitField.description: Device: VBUS Detected
BitField.name: VBUS_DETECTED

Register.description: interrupt endpoint control register
Register.name: INT_EP_CTRL

BitField.description: Host: Enable interrupt endpoint 1 -> 15
BitField.name: INT_EP_ACTIVE

Register.description: Buffer status register. A bit set here indicates that a buffer has completed on the endpoint (if the buffer interrupt is enabled). It is possible for 2 buffers to be completed, so clearing the buffer status bit may instantly re set it on the next clock cycle.
Register.name: BUFF_STATUS

Register.description: Which of the double buffers should be handled. Only valid if using an interrupt per buffer (i.e. not per 2 buffers). Not valid for host interrupt endpoint polling because they are only single buffered.
Register.name: BUFF_CPU_SHOULD_HANDLE

Register.description: Device only: Can be set to ignore the buffer control register for this endpoint in case you would like to revoke a buffer. A NAK will be sent for every access to the endpoint until this bit is cleared. A corresponding bit in `EP_ABORT_DONE` is set when it is safe to modify the buffer control register.
Register.name: EP_ABORT

Register.description: Device only: Used in conjunction with `EP_ABORT`. Set once an endpoint is idle so the programmer knows it is safe to modify the buffer control register.
Register.name: EP_ABORT_DONE

Register.description: Device: this bit must be set in conjunction with the `STALL` bit in the buffer control register to send a STALL on EP0. The device controller clears these bits when a SETUP packet is received because the USB spec requires that a STALL condition is cleared when a SETUP packet is received.
Register.name: EP_STALL_ARM

Register.description: Used by the host controller. Sets the wait time in microseconds before trying again if the device replies with a NAK.
Register.name: NAK_POLL

BitField.description: NAK polling interval for a full speed device
BitField.name: DELAY_FS

BitField.description: NAK polling interval for a low speed device
BitField.name: DELAY_LS

Register.description: Device: bits are set when the `IRQ_ON_NAK` or `IRQ_ON_STALL` bits are set. For EP0 this comes from `SIE_CTRL`. For all other endpoints it comes from the endpoint control register.
Register.name: EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK

Register.description: Where to connect the USB controller. Should be to_phy by default.
Register.name: USB_MUXING

Register.description: Overrides for the power signals in the event that the VBUS signals are not hooked up to GPIO. Set the value of the override and then the override enable to switch over to the override value.
Register.name: USB_PWR

Register.description: This register allows for direct control of the USB phy. Use in conjunction with usbphy_direct_override register to enable each override bit.
Register.name: USBPHY_DIRECT

BitField.description: DM over voltage
BitField.name: DM_OVV

BitField.description: DP over voltage
BitField.name: DP_OVV

BitField.description: DM overcurrent
BitField.name: DM_OVCN

BitField.description: DP overcurrent
BitField.name: DP_OVCN

BitField.description: DPM pin state
BitField.name: RX_DM

BitField.description: DPP pin state
BitField.name: RX_DP

BitField.description: Differential RX
BitField.name: RX_DD

BitField.description: TX_DIFFMODE=0: Single ended mode\n TX_DIFFMODE=1: Differential drive mode (TX_DM, TX_DM_OE ignored)
BitField.name: TX_DIFFMODE

BitField.description: TX_FSSLEW=0: Low speed slew rate\n TX_FSSLEW=1: Full speed slew rate
BitField.name: TX_FSSLEW

BitField.description: TX power down override (if override enable is set). 1 = powered down.
BitField.name: TX_PD

BitField.description: RX power down override (if override enable is set). 1 = powered down.
BitField.name: RX_PD

BitField.description: Output data. TX_DIFFMODE=1, Ignored\n TX_DIFFMODE=0, Drives DPM only. TX_DM_OE=1 to enable drive. DPM=TX_DM
BitField.name: TX_DM

BitField.description: Output data. If TX_DIFFMODE=1, Drives DPP/DPM diff pair. TX_DP_OE=1 to enable drive. DPP=TX_DP, DPM=~TX_DP\n If TX_DIFFMODE=0, Drives DPP only. TX_DP_OE=1 to enable drive. DPP=TX_DP
BitField.name: TX_DP

BitField.description: Output enable. If TX_DIFFMODE=1, Ignored.\n If TX_DIFFMODE=0, OE for DPM only. 0 - DPM in Hi-Z state; 1 - DPM driving
BitField.name: TX_DM_OE

BitField.description: Output enable. If TX_DIFFMODE=1, OE for DPP/DPM diff pair. 0 - DPP/DPM in Hi-Z state; 1 - DPP/DPM driving\n If TX_DIFFMODE=0, OE for DPP only. 0 - DPP in Hi-Z state; 1 - DPP driving
BitField.name: TX_DP_OE

BitField.description: DM pull down enable
BitField.name: DM_PULLDN_EN

BitField.description: DM pull up enable
BitField.name: DM_PULLUP_EN

BitField.description: Enable the second DM pull up resistor. 0 - Pull = Rpu2; 1 - Pull = Rpu1 + Rpu2
BitField.name: DM_PULLUP_HISEL

BitField.description: DP pull down enable
BitField.name: DP_PULLDN_EN

BitField.description: DP pull up enable
BitField.name: DP_PULLUP_EN

BitField.description: Enable the second DP pull up resistor. 0 - Pull = Rpu2; 1 - Pull = Rpu1 + Rpu2
BitField.name: DP_PULLUP_HISEL

Register.description: Override enable for each control in usbphy_direct
Register.name: USBPHY_DIRECT_OVERRIDE

Register.description: Used to adjust trim values of USB phy pull down resistors.
Register.name: USBPHY_TRIM

BitField.description: Value to drive to USB PHY\n DM pulldown resistor trim control\n Experimental data suggests that the reset value will work, but this register allows adjustment if required
BitField.name: DM_PULLDN_TRIM

BitField.description: Value to drive to USB PHY\n DP pulldown resistor trim control\n Experimental data suggests that the reset value will work, but this register allows adjustment if required
BitField.name: DP_PULLDN_TRIM

Register.description: Raw Interrupts
Register.name: INTR

BitField.description: Raised when any bit in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK is set. Clear by clearing all bits in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK.
BitField.name: EP_STALL_NAK

BitField.description: Raised when any bit in ABORT_DONE is set. Clear by clearing all bits in ABORT_DONE.
BitField.name: ABORT_DONE

BitField.description: Set every time the device receives a SOF (Start of Frame) packet. Cleared by reading SOF_RD
BitField.name: DEV_SOF

BitField.description: Device. Source: SIE_STATUS.SETUP_REC
BitField.name: SETUP_REQ

BitField.description: Set when the device receives a resume from the host. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.RESUME
BitField.name: DEV_RESUME_FROM_HOST

BitField.description: Set when the device suspend state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.SUSPENDED
BitField.name: DEV_SUSPEND

BitField.description: Set when the device connection state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.CONNECTED
BitField.name: DEV_CONN_DIS

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.BUS_RESET
BitField.name: BUS_RESET

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.VBUS_DETECT
BitField.name: VBUS_DETECT

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.STALL_REC
BitField.name: STALL

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.CRC_ERROR
BitField.name: ERROR_CRC

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.BIT_STUFF_ERROR
BitField.name: ERROR_BIT_STUFF

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.RX_OVERFLOW
BitField.name: ERROR_RX_OVERFLOW

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.RX_TIMEOUT
BitField.name: ERROR_RX_TIMEOUT

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.DATA_SEQ_ERROR
BitField.name: ERROR_DATA_SEQ

BitField.description: Raised when any bit in BUFF_STATUS is set. Clear by clearing all bits in BUFF_STATUS.
BitField.name: BUFF_STATUS

BitField.description: Raised every time SIE_STATUS.TRANS_COMPLETE is set. Clear by writing to this bit.
BitField.name: TRANS_COMPLETE

BitField.description: Host: raised every time the host sends a SOF (Start of Frame). Cleared by reading SOF_RD
BitField.name: HOST_SOF

BitField.description: Host: raised when a device wakes up the host. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.RESUME
BitField.name: HOST_RESUME

BitField.description: Host: raised when a device is connected or disconnected (i.e. when SIE_STATUS.SPEED changes). Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.SPEED
BitField.name: HOST_CONN_DIS

Register.description: Interrupt Enable

BitField.description: Raised when any bit in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK is set. Clear by clearing all bits in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK.

BitField.description: Raised when any bit in ABORT_DONE is set. Clear by clearing all bits in ABORT_DONE.

BitField.description: Raised every time SIE_STATUS.TRANS_COMPLETE is set. Clear by writing to this bit.

BitField.description: Set every time the device receives a SOF (Start of Frame) packet. Cleared by reading SOF_RD

BitField.description: Device. Source: SIE_STATUS.SETUP_REC
BitField.name: SETUP_REQ

BitField.description: Set when the device receives a resume from the host. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.RESUME
BitField.name: DEV_RESUME_FROM_HOST

BitField.description: Set when the device suspend state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.SUSPENDED
BitField.name: DEV_SUSPEND

BitField.description: Set when the device connection state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.CONNECTED
BitField.name: DEV_CONN_DIS

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.BUS_RESET
BitField.name: BUS_RESET

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.VBUS_DETECT
BitField.name: VBUS_DETECT

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.STALL_REC
BitField.name: STALL

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.CRC_ERROR
BitField.name: ERROR_CRC

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.BIT_STUFF_ERROR
BitField.name: ERROR_BIT_STUFF

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.RX_OVERFLOW
BitField.name: ERROR_RX_OVERFLOW

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.RX_TIMEOUT
BitField.name: ERROR_RX_TIMEOUT

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.DATA_SEQ_ERROR
BitField.name: ERROR_DATA_SEQ

BitField.description: Raised when any bit in BUFF_STATUS is set. Clear by clearing all bits in BUFF_STATUS.
BitField.name: BUFF_STATUS

BitField.description: Raised every time SIE_STATUS.TRANS_COMPLETE is set. Clear by writing to this bit.
BitField.name: TRANS_COMPLETE

BitField.description: Host: raised every time the host sends a SOF (Start of Frame). Cleared by reading SOF_RD
BitField.name: HOST_SOF

BitField.description: Host: raised when a device wakes up the host. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.RESUME
BitField.name: HOST_RESUME

BitField.description: Host: raised when a device is connected or disconnected (i.e. when SIE_STATUS.SPEED changes). Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.SPEED
BitField.name: HOST_CONN_DIS

Register.description: Interrupt status after masking & forcing
Register.name: INTS

BitField.description: Raised when any bit in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK is set. Clear by clearing all bits in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK.
BitField.name: EP_STALL_NAK

BitField.description: Raised when any bit in ABORT_DONE is set. Clear by clearing all bits in ABORT_DONE.
BitField.name: ABORT_DONE

BitField.name: DEV_SOF

BitField.name: DEV_CONN_DIS

BitField.name: BUS_RESET

BitField.name: VBUS_DETECT

BitField.name: STALL

BitField.name: ERROR_CRC

BitField.name: ERROR_BIT_STUFF

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.RX_OVERFLOW
BitField.name: ERROR_RX_OVERFLOW

BitField.description: Source: SIE_STATUS.RX_TIMEOUT
BitField.name: ERROR_RX_TIMEOUT

BitField.name: ERROR_DATA_SEQ

BitField.name: BUFF_STATUS

BitField.description: Host: raised every time the host sends a SOF (Start of Frame). Cleared by reading SOF_RD
BitField.name: HOST_SOF

BitField.name: HOST_RESUME

BitField.name: HOST_CONN_DIS

Register.description: PIO control register
Register.name: CTRL

BitField.description: Force clock dividers to restart their count and clear fractional\n accumulators. Restart multiple dividers to synchronise them.
BitField.name: CLKDIV_RESTART

BitField.description: Clear internal SM state which is otherwise difficult to access\n (e.g. shift counters). Self-clearing.
BitField.name: SM_RESTART

BitField.description: Enable state machine
BitField.name: SM_ENABLE

Register.description: FIFO status register
Register.name: FSTAT

BitField.description: State machine TX FIFO is empty
BitField.name: TXEMPTY

BitField.description: State machine TX FIFO is full
BitField.name: TXFULL

BitField.description: State machine RX FIFO is empty
BitField.name: RXEMPTY

BitField.description: State machine RX FIFO is full
BitField.name: RXFULL

Register.description: FIFO debug register
Register.name: FDEBUG

BitField.description: State machine has stalled on empty TX FIFO. Write 1 to clear.
BitField.name: TXSTALL

BitField.description: TX FIFO overflow has occurred. Write 1 to clear.
BitField.name: TXOVER

BitField.description: RX FIFO underflow has occurred. Write 1 to clear.
BitField.name: RXUNDER

BitField.description: State machine has stalled on full RX FIFO. Write 1 to clear.
BitField.name: RXSTALL

Register.description: FIFO levels
Register.name: FLEVEL

Register.description: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.
Register.name: TXF0

Register.description: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.
Register.name: TXF1

Register.description: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.
Register.name: TXF2

Register.description: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.
Register.name: TXF3

Register.description: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.
Register.name: RXF0

Register.description: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.
Register.name: RXF1

Register.description: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.
Register.name: RXF2

Register.description: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.
Register.name: RXF3

Register.description: Interrupt request register. Write 1 to clear
Register.name: IRQ

Register.description:
Writing a 1 to each of these bits will forcibly assert the corresponding IRQ.
 Note this is different to the INTF register: writing here affects PIO internal
 state. INTF just asserts the processor-facing IRQ signal for testing ISRs,
 and is not visible to the state machines.
Register.name: IRQ_FORCE

Register.description:
There is a 2-flipflop synchronizer on each GPIO input, which protects
 PIO logic from metastabilities. This increases input delay, and for fast
 synchronous IO (e.g. SPI) these synchronizers may need to be bypassed.
 Each bit in this register corresponds to one GPIO.
 0 -> input is synchronized (default)
 1 -> synchronizer is bypassed
 If in doubt, leave this register as all zeroes.
Register.name: INPUT_SYNC_BYPASS

Register.description: Read to sample the pad output values PIO is currently driving to the GPIOs.
Register.name: DBG_PADOUT

Register.description: Read to sample the pad output enables (direction) PIO is currently driving to the GPIOs.
Register.name: DBG_PADOE

Register.description: The PIO hardware has some free parameters that may vary between chip products.\n These should be provided in the chip datasheet, but are also exposed here.
Register.name: DBG_CFGINFO

BitField.description: The size of the instruction memory, measured in units of one instruction
BitField.name: IMEM_SIZE

BitField.description: The number of state machines this PIO instance is equipped with.
BitField.name: SM_COUNT

BitField.description: The depth of the state machine TX/RX FIFOs, measured in words.\n Joining fifos via SHIFTCTRL_FJOIN gives one FIFO with double\n this depth.
BitField.name: FIFO_DEPTH

Register.name: INSTR_MEM0

Register.description: Clock divider register for state machine 0\n Frequency = clock freq / (CLKDIV_INT + CLKDIV_FRAC / 256)
Register.name: SM0_CLKDIV

BitField.description: Effective frequency is sysclk/int.\n Value of 0 is interpreted as max possible value
BitField.name: INT

BitField.description: Fractional part of clock divider
BitField.name: FRAC

Register.description: Execution/behavioural settings for state machine 0
Register.name: SM0_EXECCTRL

BitField.description: An instruction written to SMx_INSTR is stalled, and latched by the\n state machine. Will clear once the instruction completes.
BitField.name: EXEC_STALLED

BitField.description: If 1, the delay MSB is used as side-set enable, rather than a\n side-set data bit. This allows instructions to perform side-set optionally,\n rather than on every instruction.
BitField.name: SIDE_EN

BitField.description: Side-set data is asserted to pin OEs instead of pin values
BitField.name: SIDE_PINDIR

BitField.description: The GPIO number to use as condition for JMP PIN. Unaffected by input mapping.
BitField.name: JMP_PIN

BitField.description: Which data bit to use for inline OUT enable
BitField.name: OUT_EN_SEL

BitField.description:
If 1, use a bit of OUT data as an auxiliary write enable
 When used in conjunction with OUT_STICKY, writes with an enable of 0 will
 deassert the latest pin write. This can create useful masking/override behaviour
 due to the priority ordering of state machine pin writes (SM0 < SM1 < ...)
BitField.name: INLINE_OUT_EN

BitField.description: Continuously assert the most recent OUT/SET to the pins
BitField.name: OUT_STICKY

BitField.description: After reaching this address, execution is wrapped to wrap_bottom.\n If the instruction is a jump, and the jump condition is true, the jump takes priority.
BitField.name: WRAP_TOP

BitField.description: After reaching wrap_top, execution is wrapped to this address.
BitField.name: WRAP_BOTTOM

BitField.description: Comparison used for the MOV x, STATUS instruction.
BitField.name: STATUS_SEL

Enum.description: All-ones if TX FIFO level < N, otherwise all-zeroes
Enum.name: TXLEVEL

Enum.description: All-ones if RX FIFO level < N, otherwise all-zeroes
Enum.name: RXLEVEL

BitField.description: Comparison level for the MOV x, STATUS instruction
BitField.name: STATUS_N

Register.description: Control behaviour of the input/output shift registers for state machine 0
Register.name: SM0_SHIFTCTRL

BitField.description: When 1, RX FIFO steals the TX FIFO's storage, and becomes twice as deep.\n TX FIFO is disabled as a result (always reads as both full and empty).\n FIFOs are flushed when this bit is changed.
BitField.name: FJOIN_RX

BitField.description: When 1, TX FIFO steals the RX FIFO's storage, and becomes twice as deep.\n RX FIFO is disabled as a result (always reads as both full and empty).\n FIFOs are flushed when this bit is changed.
BitField.name: FJOIN_TX

BitField.description: Number of bits shifted out of TXSR before autopull or conditional pull.\n Write 0 for value of 32.
BitField.name: PULL_THRESH

BitField.description: Number of bits shifted into RXSR before autopush or conditional push.\n Write 0 for value of 32.
BitField.name: PUSH_THRESH

BitField.description: 1 = shift out of output shift register to right. 0 = to left.
BitField.name: OUT_SHIFTDIR

BitField.description: 1 = shift input shift register to right (data enters from left). 0 = to left.
BitField.name: IN_SHIFTDIR

BitField.description: Pull automatically when the output shift register is emptied
BitField.name: AUTOPULL

BitField.description: Push automatically when the input shift register is filled
BitField.name: AUTOPUSH

Register.description: Current instruction address of state machine 0
Register.name: SM0_ADDR

Register.description: Instruction currently being executed by state machine 0\n Write to execute an instruction immediately (including jumps) and then resume execution.
Register.name: SM0_INSTR

Register.description: State machine pin control
Register.name: SM0_PINCTRL

BitField.description: The number of delay bits co-opted for side-set. Inclusive of the enable bit, if present.
BitField.name: SIDESET_COUNT

BitField.description: The number of pins asserted by a SET. Max of 5
BitField.name: SET_COUNT

BitField.description: The number of pins asserted by an OUT. Value of 0 -> 32 pins
BitField.name: OUT_COUNT

BitField.description: The virtual pin corresponding to IN bit 0
BitField.name: IN_BASE

BitField.description: The virtual pin corresponding to delay field bit 0
BitField.name: SIDESET_BASE

BitField.description: The virtual pin corresponding to SET bit 0
BitField.name: SET_BASE

BitField.description: The virtual pin corresponding to OUT bit 0
BitField.name: OUT_BASE

Register.description: Control behaviour of the input/output shift registers for state machine 3
Register.name: SM3_SHIFTCTRL

BitField.description: When 1, RX FIFO steals the TX FIFO's storage, and becomes twice as deep.\n TX FIFO is disabled as a result (always reads as both full and empty).\n FIFOs are flushed when this bit is changed.
BitField.name: FJOIN_RX

BitField.description: When 1, TX FIFO steals the RX FIFO's storage, and becomes twice as deep.\n RX FIFO is disabled as a result (always reads as both full and empty).\n FIFOs are flushed when this bit is changed.
BitField.name: FJOIN_TX

BitField.description: Number of bits shifted out of TXSR before autopull or conditional pull.\n Write 0 for value of 32.
BitField.name: PULL_THRESH

BitField.description: Number of bits shifted into RXSR before autopush or conditional push.\n Write 0 for value of 32.
BitField.name: PUSH_THRESH

BitField.description: 1 = shift out of output shift register to right. 0 = to left.
BitField.name: OUT_SHIFTDIR

BitField.description: 1 = shift input shift register to right (data enters from left). 0 = to left.
BitField.name: IN_SHIFTDIR

BitField.description: Pull automatically when the output shift register is emptied
BitField.name: AUTOPULL

BitField.description: Push automatically when the input shift register is filled
BitField.name: AUTOPUSH

Register.description: Current instruction address of state machine 3
Register.name: SM3_ADDR

Register.description: Instruction currently being executed by state machine 3\n Write to execute an instruction immediately (including jumps) and then resume execution.
Register.name: SM3_INSTR

Register.description: State machine pin control
Register.name: SM3_PINCTRL

BitField.description: The number of delay bits co-opted for side-set. Inclusive of the enable bit, if present.
BitField.name: SIDESET_COUNT

BitField.description: The number of pins asserted by a SET. Max of 5
BitField.name: SET_COUNT

BitField.description: The number of pins asserted by an OUT. Value of 0 -> 32 pins
BitField.name: OUT_COUNT

BitField.description: The virtual pin corresponding to IN bit 0
BitField.name: IN_BASE

BitField.description: The virtual pin corresponding to delay field bit 0
BitField.name: SIDESET_BASE

BitField.description: The virtual pin corresponding to SET bit 0
BitField.name: SET_BASE

BitField.description: The virtual pin corresponding to OUT bit 0
BitField.name: OUT_BASE

Register.description: Raw Interrupts
Register.name: INTR

Register.description: Interrupt Enable for irq0
Register.name: IRQ0_INTE

Register.description: Interrupt Force for irq0
Register.name: IRQ0_INTF

Register.description: Interrupt status after masking & forcing for irq0
Register.name: IRQ0_INTS

Register.description: Interrupt Enable for irq1
Register.name: IRQ1_INTE

Register.description: Interrupt Force for irq1
Register.name: IRQ1_INTF

Register.description: Interrupt status after masking & forcing for irq1
Register.name: IRQ1_INTS

Register.description: PIO control register
Register.name: CTRL

BitField.description: Force clock dividers to restart their count and clear fractional\n accumulators. Restart multiple dividers to synchronise them.
BitField.name: CLKDIV_RESTART

BitField.description: Clear internal SM state which is otherwise difficult to access\n (e.g. shift counters). Self-clearing.
BitField.name: SM_RESTART

BitField.description: Enable state machine
BitField.name: SM_ENABLE

Register.description: FIFO status register
Register.name: FSTAT

BitField.description: State machine TX FIFO is empty
BitField.name: TXEMPTY

BitField.description: State machine TX FIFO is full
BitField.name: TXFULL

BitField.description: State machine RX FIFO is empty
BitField.name: RXEMPTY

BitField.description: State machine RX FIFO is full
BitField.name: RXFULL

Register.description: FIFO debug register
Register.name: FDEBUG

BitField.description: State machine has stalled on empty TX FIFO. Write 1 to clear.
BitField.name: TXSTALL

BitField.description: TX FIFO overflow has occurred. Write 1 to clear.
BitField.name: TXOVER

BitField.description: RX FIFO underflow has occurred. Write 1 to clear.
BitField.name: RXUNDER

BitField.description: State machine has stalled on full RX FIFO. Write 1 to clear.
BitField.name: RXSTALL

Register.description: FIFO levels
Register.name: FLEVEL

Register.description: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.
Register.name: TXF0

Register.description: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.
Register.name: TXF1

Register.description: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.
Register.name: TXF2

Register.description: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.
Register.name: TXF3

Register.description: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.
Register.name: RXF0

Register.description: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.
Register.name: RXF1

Register.description: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.
Register.name: RXF2

Register.description: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.
Register.name: RXF3

Register.description: Interrupt request register. Write 1 to clear
Register.name: IRQ

Register.description:
Writing a 1 to each of these bits will forcibly assert the corresponding IRQ.
 Note this is different to the INTF register: writing here affects PIO internal
 state. INTF just asserts the processor-facing IRQ signal for testing ISRs,
 and is not visible to the state machines.
Register.name: IRQ_FORCE

Register.description:
There is a 2-flipflop synchronizer on each GPIO input, which protects
 PIO logic from metastabilities. This increases input delay, and for fast
 synchronous IO (e.g. SPI) these synchronizers may need to be bypassed.
 Each bit in this register corresponds to one GPIO.
 0 -> input is synchronized (default)
 1 -> synchronizer is bypassed
 If in doubt, leave this register as all zeroes.
Register.name: INPUT_SYNC_BYPASS

Register.description: Read to sample the pad output values PIO is currently driving to the GPIOs.
Register.name: DBG_PADOUT

Register.description: Read to sample the pad output enables (direction) PIO is currently driving to the GPIOs.
Register.name: DBG_PADOE

Register.description: The PIO hardware has some free parameters that may vary between chip products.\n These should be provided in the chip datasheet, but are also exposed here.
Register.name: DBG_CFGINFO

BitField.description: The size of the instruction memory, measured in units of one instruction
BitField.name: IMEM_SIZE

BitField.description: The number of state machines this PIO instance is equipped with.
BitField.name: SM_COUNT

BitField.description: The depth of the state machine TX/RX FIFOs, measured in words.\n Joining fifos via SHIFTCTRL_FJOIN gives one FIFO with double\n this depth.
BitField.name: FIFO_DEPTH

Register.name: INSTR_MEM0

Register.description: Clock divider register for state machine 0\n Frequency = clock freq / (CLKDIV_INT + CLKDIV_FRAC / 256)
Register.name: SM0_CLKDIV

BitField.description: Effective frequency is sysclk/int.\n Value of 0 is interpreted as max possible value
BitField.name: INT

BitField.description: Fractional part of clock divider
BitField.name: FRAC

Register.description: Execution/behavioural settings for state machine 0
Register.name: SM0_EXECCTRL

BitField.description: An instruction written to SMx_INSTR is stalled, and latched by the\n state machine. Will clear once the instruction completes.
BitField.name: EXEC_STALLED

BitField.description: If 1, the delay MSB is used as side-set enable, rather than a\n side-set data bit. This allows instructions to perform side-set optionally,\n rather than on every instruction.
BitField.name: SIDE_EN

BitField.description: Side-set data is asserted to pin OEs instead of pin values
BitField.name: SIDE_PINDIR

BitField.description: The GPIO number to use as condition for JMP PIN. Unaffected by input mapping.
BitField.name: JMP_PIN

BitField.description: Which data bit to use for inline OUT enable
BitField.name: OUT_EN_SEL

BitField.description:
If 1, use a bit of OUT data as an auxiliary write enable
 When used in conjunction with OUT_STICKY, writes with an enable of 0 will
 deassert the latest pin write. This can create useful masking/override behaviour
 due to the priority ordering of state machine pin writes (SM0 < SM1 < ...)
BitField.name: INLINE_OUT_EN

BitField.description: Continuously assert the most recent OUT/SET to the pins
BitField.name: OUT_STICKY

BitField.description: After reaching this address, execution is wrapped to wrap_bottom.\n If the instruction is a jump, and the jump condition is true, the jump takes priority.
BitField.name: WRAP_TOP

BitField.description: After reaching wrap_top, execution is wrapped to this address.
BitField.name: WRAP_BOTTOM

BitField.description: Comparison used for the MOV x, STATUS instruction.
BitField.name: STATUS_SEL

Enum.description: All-ones if TX FIFO level < N, otherwise all-zeroes
Enum.name: TXLEVEL

Enum.description: All-ones if RX FIFO level < N, otherwise all-zeroes
Enum.name: RXLEVEL

BitField.description: Comparison level for the MOV x, STATUS instruction
BitField.name: STATUS_N

BitField.name: SIDESET_BASE

BitField.description: The virtual pin corresponding to SET bit 0
BitField.name: SET_BASE

BitField.description: The virtual pin corresponding to OUT bit 0
BitField.name: OUT_BASE

Register.description: Raw Interrupts
Register.name: INTR

Register.name: IRQ0_INTE

Register.name: IRQ0_INTF

Register.description: Interrupt status after masking & forcing for irq0

RegisterGroup.description: Single-cycle IO block\n Provides core-local and inter-core hardware for the two processors, with single-cycle access.
RegisterGroup.name: SIO

Register.description: Processor core identifier\n Value is 0 when read from processor core 0, and 1 when read from processor core 1.
Register.name: CPUID

Register.description: Input value for GPIO pins
Register.name: GPIO_IN

BitField.description: Input value for GPIO0...29
BitField.name: GPIO_IN

Register.description: Input value for QSPI pins
Register.name: GPIO_HI_IN

BitField.description: Input value on QSPI IO in order 0..5: SCLK, SSn, SD0, SD1, SD2, SD3
BitField.name: GPIO_HI_IN

Register.description: GPIO output value
Register.name: GPIO_OUT

BitField.description:
Set output level (1/0 -> high/low) for GPIO0...29.
 Reading back gives the last value written, NOT the input value from the pins.
 If core 0 and core 1 both write to GPIO_OUT simultaneously (or to a SET/CLR/XOR alias),
 the result is as though the write from core 0 took place first,
 and the write from core 1 was then applied to that intermediate result.
BitField.name: GPIO_OUT

Register.description: GPIO output value set
Register.name: GPIO_OUT_SET

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bit-set on GPIO_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_OUT |= wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_OUT_SET

Register.description: GPIO output value clear
Register.name: GPIO_OUT_CLR

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bit-clear on GPIO_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_OUT &= ~wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_OUT_CLR

Register.description: GPIO output value XOR
Register.name: GPIO_OUT_XOR

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bitwise XOR on GPIO_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_OUT ^= wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_OUT_XOR

Register.description: GPIO output enable
Register.name: GPIO_OE

BitField.description:
Set output enable (1/0 -> output/input) for GPIO0...29.
 Reading back gives the last value written.
 If core 0 and core 1 both write to GPIO_OE simultaneously (or to a SET/CLR/XOR alias),
 the result is as though the write from core 0 took place first,
 and the write from core 1 was then applied to that intermediate result.
BitField.name: GPIO_OE

Register.description: GPIO output enable set
Register.name: GPIO_OE_SET

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bit-set on GPIO_OE, i.e. `GPIO_OE |= wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_OE_SET

Register.description: GPIO output enable clear
Register.name: GPIO_OE_CLR

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bit-clear on GPIO_OE, i.e. `GPIO_OE &= ~wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_OE_CLR

Register.description: GPIO output enable XOR
Register.name: GPIO_OE_XOR

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bitwise XOR on GPIO_OE, i.e. `GPIO_OE ^= wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_OE_XOR

Register.description: QSPI output value
Register.name: GPIO_HI_OUT

BitField.description:
Set output level (1/0 -> high/low) for QSPI IO0...5.
 Reading back gives the last value written, NOT the input value from the pins.
 If core 0 and core 1 both write to GPIO_HI_OUT simultaneously (or to a SET/CLR/XOR alias),
 the result is as though the write from core 0 took place first,
 and the write from core 1 was then applied to that intermediate result.
BitField.name: GPIO_HI_OUT

Register.description: QSPI output value set
Register.name: GPIO_HI_OUT_SET

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bit-set on GPIO_HI_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OUT |= wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_HI_OUT_SET

Register.description: QSPI output value clear
Register.name: GPIO_HI_OUT_CLR

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bit-clear on GPIO_HI_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OUT &= ~wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_HI_OUT_CLR

Register.description: QSPI output value XOR
Register.name: GPIO_HI_OUT_XOR

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bitwise XOR on GPIO_HI_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OUT ^= wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_HI_OUT_XOR

Register.description: QSPI output enable
Register.name: GPIO_HI_OE

BitField.description:
Set output enable (1/0 -> output/input) for QSPI IO0...5.
 Reading back gives the last value written.
 If core 0 and core 1 both write to GPIO_HI_OE simultaneously (or to a SET/CLR/XOR alias),
 the result is as though the write from core 0 took place first,
 and the write from core 1 was then applied to that intermediate result.
BitField.name: GPIO_HI_OE

Register.description: QSPI output enable set
Register.name: GPIO_HI_OE_SET

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bit-set on GPIO_HI_OE, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OE |= wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_HI_OE_SET

Register.description: QSPI output enable clear
Register.name: GPIO_HI_OE_CLR

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bit-clear on GPIO_HI_OE, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OE &= ~wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_HI_OE_CLR

Register.description: QSPI output enable XOR
Register.name: GPIO_HI_OE_XOR

BitField.description: Perform an atomic bitwise XOR on GPIO_HI_OE, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OE ^= wdata`
BitField.name: GPIO_HI_OE_XOR

Register.description:
Status register for inter-core FIFOs (mailboxes).
 There is one FIFO in the core 0 -> core 1 direction, and one core 1 -> core 0. Both are 32 bits wide and 8 words deep.
 Core 0 can see the read side of the 1->0 FIFO (RX), and the write side of 0->1 FIFO (TX).
 Core 1 can see the read side of the 0->1 FIFO (RX), and the write side of 1->0 FIFO (TX).
 The SIO IRQ for each core is the logical OR of the VLD, WOF and ROE fields of its FIFO_ST register.
Register.name: FIFO_ST

BitField.description: Sticky flag indicating the RX FIFO was read when empty. This read was ignored by the FIFO.
BitField.name: ROE

BitField.description: Sticky flag indicating the TX FIFO was written when full. This write was ignored by the FIFO.
BitField.name: WOF

BitField.description: Value is 1 if this core's TX FIFO is not full (i.e. if FIFO_WR is ready for more data)
BitField.name: RDY

BitField.description: Value is 1 if this core's RX FIFO is not empty (i.e. if FIFO_RD is valid)
BitField.name: VLD

Register.description: Write access to this core's TX FIFO
Register.name: FIFO_WR

Register.description: Read access to this core's RX FIFO
Register.name: FIFO_RD

Register.description: Spinlock state\n A bitmap containing the state of all 32 spinlocks (1=locked).\n Mainly intended for debugging.
Register.name: SPINLOCK_ST

Register.description:
Divider unsigned dividend
 Write to the DIVIDEND operand of the divider, i.e. the p in `p / q`.
 Any operand write starts a new calculation. The results appear in QUOTIENT, REMAINDER.
 UDIVIDEND/SDIVIDEND are aliases of the same internal register. The U alias starts an
 unsigned calculation, and the S alias starts a signed calculation.
Register.name: DIV_UDIVIDEND

Register.description:
Divider unsigned divisor
 Write to the DIVISOR operand of the divider, i.e. the q in `p / q`.
 Any operand write starts a new calculation. The results appear in QUOTIENT, REMAINDER.
 UDIVIDEND/SDIVIDEND are aliases of the same internal register. The U alias starts an
 unsigned calculation, and the S alias starts a signed calculation.
Register.name: DIV_UDIVISOR

Register.description: Divider signed dividend\n The same as UDIVIDEND, but starts a signed calculation, rather than unsigned.
Register.name: DIV_SDIVIDEND

Register.description: Divider signed divisor\n The same as UDIVISOR, but starts a signed calculation, rather than unsigned.
Register.name: DIV_SDIVISOR

Register.description:
Divider result quotient
 The result of `DIVIDEND / DIVISOR` (division). Contents undefined while CSR_READY is low.
 For signed calculations, QUOTIENT is negative when the signs of DIVIDEND and DIVISOR differ.
 This register can be written to directly, for context save/restore purposes. This halts any
 in-progress calculation and sets the CSR_READY and CSR_DIRTY flags.
 Reading from QUOTIENT clears the CSR_DIRTY flag, so should read results in the order
 REMAINDER, QUOTIENT if CSR_DIRTY is used.
Register.name: DIV_QUOTIENT

Register.description:
Divider result remainder
 The result of `DIVIDEND % DIVISOR` (modulo). Contents undefined while CSR_READY is low.
 For signed calculations, REMAINDER is negative only when DIVIDEND is negative.
 This register can be written to directly, for context save/restore purposes. This halts any
 in-progress calculation and sets the CSR_READY and CSR_DIRTY flags.
Register.name: DIV_REMAINDER

Register.description: Control and status register for divider.
Register.name: DIV_CSR

BitField.description:
Changes to 1 when any register is written, and back to 0 when QUOTIENT is read.
 Software can use this flag to make save/restore more efficient (skip if not DIRTY).
 If the flag is used in this way, it's recommended to either read QUOTIENT only,
 or REMAINDER and then QUOTIENT, to prevent data loss on context switch.
BitField.name: DIRTY

BitField.description:
Reads as 0 when a calculation is in progress, 1 otherwise.
 Writing an operand (xDIVIDEND, xDIVISOR) will immediately start a new calculation, no
 matter if one is already in progress.
 Writing to a result register will immediately terminate any in-progress calculation
 and set the READY and DIRTY flags.
BitField.name: READY

Register.description: Read/write access to accumulator 0
Register.name: INTERP0_ACCUM0

Register.description: Read/write access to accumulator 1
Register.name: INTERP0_ACCUM1

Register.description: Read/write access to BASE0 register.
Register.name: INTERP0_BASE0

Register.description: Read/write access to BASE1 register.
Register.name: INTERP0_BASE1

Register.description: Read/write access to BASE2 register.
Register.name: INTERP0_BASE2

Register.description: Read LANE0 result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).
Register.name: INTERP0_POP_LANE0

Register.description: Read LANE1 result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).
Register.name: INTERP0_POP_LANE1

Register.description: Read FULL result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).
Register.name: INTERP0_POP_FULL

Register.description: Read LANE0 result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).
Register.name: INTERP0_PEEK_LANE0

Register.description: Read LANE1 result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).
Register.name: INTERP0_PEEK_LANE1

Register.description: Read FULL result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).
Register.name: INTERP0_PEEK_FULL

Register.description: Control register for lane 0
Register.name: INTERP0_CTRL_LANE0

BitField.description: Set if either OVERF0 or OVERF1 is set.
BitField.name: OVERF

BitField.description: Indicates if any masked-off MSBs in ACCUM1 are set.
BitField.name: OVERF1

BitField.description: Indicates if any masked-off MSBs in ACCUM0 are set.
BitField.name: OVERF0

BitField.description:
Only present on INTERP0 on each core. If BLEND mode is enabled:
 - LANE1 result is a linear interpolation between BASE0 and BASE1, controlled
 by the 8 LSBs of lane 1 shift and mask value (a fractional number between
 0 and 255/256ths)
 - LANE0 result does not have BASE0 added (yields only the 8 LSBs of lane 1 shift+mask value)
 - FULL result does not have lane 1 shift+mask value added (BASE2 + lane 0 shift+mask)
 LANE1 SIGNED flag controls whether the interpolation is signed or unsigned.
BitField.name: BLEND

BitField.description: ORed into bits 29:28 of the lane result presented to the processor on the bus.\n No effect on the internal 32-bit datapath. Handy for using a lane to generate sequence\n of pointers into flash or SRAM.
BitField.name: FORCE_MSB

BitField.description: If 1, mask + shift is bypassed for LANE0 result. This does not affect FULL result.
BitField.name: ADD_RAW

BitField.description: If 1, feed the opposite lane's result into this lane's accumulator on POP.
BitField.name: CROSS_RESULT

BitField.description: If 1, feed the opposite lane's accumulator into this lane's shift + mask hardware.\n Takes effect even if ADD_RAW is set (the CROSS_INPUT mux is before the shift+mask bypass)
BitField.name: CROSS_INPUT

BitField.description: If SIGNED is set, the shifted and masked accumulator value is sign-extended to 32 bits\n before adding to BASE0, and LANE0 PEEK/POP appear extended to 32 bits when read by processor.
BitField.name: SIGNED

BitField.description: The most-significant bit allowed to pass by the mask (inclusive)\n Setting MSB < LSB may cause chip to turn inside-out
BitField.name: MASK_MSB

BitField.description: The least-significant bit allowed to pass by the mask (inclusive)
BitField.name: MASK_LSB

BitField.description: Logical right-shift applied to accumulator before masking
BitField.name: SHIFT

Register.description: Control register for lane 1
Register.name: INTERP0_CTRL_LANE1

BitField.description: ORed into bits 29:28 of the lane result presented to the processor on the bus.\n No effect on the internal 32-bit datapath. Handy for using a lane to generate sequence\n of pointers into flash or SRAM.
BitField.name: FORCE_MSB

BitField.description: If 1, mask + shift is bypassed for LANE1 result. This does not affect FULL result.
BitField.name: ADD_RAW

BitField.description: If 1, feed the opposite lane's result into this lane's accumulator on POP.
BitField.name: CROSS_RESULT

BitField.description: If 1, feed the opposite lane's accumulator into this lane's shift + mask hardware.\n Takes effect even if ADD_RAW is set (the CROSS_INPUT mux is before the shift+mask bypass)
BitField.name: CROSS_INPUT

BitField.description: If SIGNED is set, the shifted and masked accumulator value is sign-extended to 32 bits\n before adding to BASE1, and LANE1 PEEK/POP appear extended to 32 bits when read by processor.
BitField.name: SIGNED

BitField.description: The most-significant bit allowed to pass by the mask (inclusive)\n Setting MSB < LSB may cause chip to turn inside-out
BitField.name: MASK_MSB

BitField.description: The least-significant bit allowed to pass by the mask (inclusive)
BitField.name: MASK_LSB

BitField.description: Logical right-shift applied to accumulator before masking
BitField.name: SHIFT

Register.description: Values written here are atomically added to ACCUM0\n Reading yields lane 0's raw shift and mask value (BASE0 not added).
Register.name: INTERP0_ACCUM0_ADD

Register.description: Values written here are atomically added to ACCUM1\n Reading yields lane 1's raw shift and mask value (BASE1 not added).
Register.name: INTERP0_ACCUM1_ADD

Register.description: On write, the lower 16 bits go to BASE0, upper bits to BASE1 simultaneously.\n Each half is sign-extended to 32 bits if that lane's SIGNED flag is set.
Register.name: INTERP0_BASE_1AND0

Register.description: Read/write access to accumulator 0
Register.name: INTERP1_ACCUM0

Register.description: Read/write access to accumulator 1
Register.name: INTERP1_ACCUM1

Register.description: Read/write access to BASE0 register.
Register.name: INTERP1_BASE0

Register.description: Read/write access to BASE1 register.
Register.name: INTERP1_BASE1

Register.description: Read/write access to BASE2 register.
Register.name: INTERP1_BASE2

Register.description: Read LANE0 result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).
Register.name: INTERP1_POP_LANE0

Register.description: Read LANE1 result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).
Register.name: INTERP1_POP_LANE1

Register.description: Read FULL result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).
Register.name: INTERP1_POP_FULL

Register.description: Read LANE0 result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).
Register.name: INTERP1_PEEK_LANE0

Register.description: Read LANE1 result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).
Register.name: INTERP1_PEEK_LANE1

Register.description: Read FULL result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).
Register.name: INTERP1_PEEK_FULL

Register.description: Control register for lane 0
Register.name: INTERP1_CTRL_LANE0

BitField.description: Set if either OVERF0 or OVERF1 is set.
BitField.name: OVERF

BitField.description: Indicates if any masked-off MSBs in ACCUM1 are set.
BitField.name: OVERF1

BitField.description: Indicates if any masked-off MSBs in ACCUM0 are set.
BitField.name: OVERF0

BitField.description:
Only present on INTERP1 on each core. If CLAMP mode is enabled:
 - LANE0 result is shifted and masked ACCUM0, clamped by a lower bound of
 BASE0 and an upper bound of BASE1.
 - Signedness of these comparisons is determined by LANE0_CTRL_SIGNED
BitField.name: CLAMP

Register.description:
Reading from a spinlock address will:
 - Return 0 if lock is already locked
 - Otherwise return nonzero, and simultaneously claim the lock

 Writing (any value) releases the lock.
 If core 0 and core 1 attempt to claim the same lock simultaneously, core 0 wins.
 The value returned on success is 0x1 << lock number.
Register.name: SPINLOCK0

Register.description:
Reading from a spinlock address will:
 - Return 0 if lock is already locked
 - Otherwise return nonzero, and simultaneously claim the lock

 Writing (any value) releases the lock.
 If core 0 and core 1 attempt to claim the same lock simultaneously, core 0 wins.
 The value returned on success is 0x1 << lock number.
Register.name: SPINLOCK1

 The value returned on success is 0x1 << lock number.
Register.name: SPINLOCK20

Register.description:
Reading from a spinlock address will:
 - Return 0 if lock is already locked
 - Otherwise return nonzero, and simultaneously claim the lock

 Writing (any value) releases the lock.
 If core 0 and core 1 attempt to claim the same lock simultaneously, core 0 wins.
 The value returned on success is 0x1 << lock number.
Register.name: SPINLOCK21

 - Otherwise return nonzero, and simultaneously claim the lock

 Writing (any value) releases the lock.
 If core 0 and core 1 attempt to claim the same lock simultaneously, core 0 wins.
 The value returned on success is 0x1 << lock number.

Register.description: Use the SysTick Control and Status Register to enable the SysTick features.
Register.name: SYST_CSR

BitField.description: Returns 1 if timer counted to 0 since last time this was read. Clears on read by application or debugger.
BitField.name: COUNTFLAG

BitField.description:
SysTick clock source. Always reads as one if SYST_CALIB reports NOREF.
 Selects the SysTick timer clock source:
 0 = External reference clock.
 1 = Processor clock.
BitField.name: CLKSOURCE

BitField.description: Enables SysTick exception request:\n 0 = Counting down to zero does not assert the SysTick exception request.\n 1 = Counting down to zero to asserts the SysTick exception request.
BitField.name: TICKINT

BitField.description: Enable SysTick counter:\n 0 = Counter disabled.\n 1 = Counter enabled.
BitField.name: ENABLE

Register.description: Use the SysTick Reload Value Register to specify the start value to load into the current value register when the counter reaches 0. It can be any value between 0 and 0x00FFFFFF. A start value of 0 is possible, but has no effect because the SysTick interrupt and COUNTFLAG are activated when counting from 1 to 0. The reset value of this register is UNKNOWN.\n To generate a multi-shot timer with a period of N processor clock cycles, use a RELOAD value of N-1. For example, if the SysTick interrupt is required every 100 clock pulses, set RELOAD to 99.
Register.name: SYST_RVR

BitField.description: Value to load into the SysTick Current Value Register when the counter reaches 0.
BitField.name: RELOAD

Register.description: Use the SysTick Current Value Register to find the current value in the register. The reset value of this register is UNKNOWN.
Register.name: SYST_CVR

BitField.description: Reads return the current value of the SysTick counter. This register is write-clear. Writing to it with any value clears the register to 0. Clearing this register also clears the COUNTFLAG bit of the SysTick Control and Status Register.
BitField.name: CURRENT

Register.description: Use the SysTick Calibration Value Register to enable software to scale to any required speed using divide and multiply.
Register.name: SYST_CALIB

BitField.description: If reads as 1, the Reference clock is not provided - the CLKSOURCE bit of the SysTick Control and Status register will be forced to 1 and cannot be cleared to 0.
BitField.name: NOREF

BitField.description: If reads as 1, the calibration value for 10ms is inexact (due to clock frequency).
BitField.name: SKEW

BitField.description: An optional Reload value to be used for 10ms (100Hz) timing, subject to system clock skew errors. If the value reads as 0, the calibration value is not known.
BitField.name: TENMS

Register.description: Use the Interrupt Set-Enable Register to enable interrupts and determine which interrupts are currently enabled.\n If a pending interrupt is enabled, the NVIC activates the interrupt based on its priority. If an interrupt is not enabled, asserting its interrupt signal changes the interrupt state to pending, but the NVIC never activates the interrupt, regardless of its priority.
Register.name: NVIC_ISER

BitField.description:
Interrupt set-enable bits.
 Write:
 0 = No effect.
 1 = Enable interrupt.
 Read:
 0 = Interrupt disabled.
 1 = Interrupt enabled.
BitField.name: SETENA

Register.description: Use the Interrupt Clear-Enable Registers to disable interrupts and determine which interrupts are currently enabled.
Register.name: NVIC_ICER

BitField.description:
Interrupt clear-enable bits.
 Write:
 0 = No effect.
 1 = Disable interrupt.
 Read:
 0 = Interrupt disabled.
 1 = Interrupt enabled.
BitField.name: CLRENA

Register.description: The NVIC_ISPR forces interrupts into the pending state, and shows which interrupts are pending.
Register.name: NVIC_ISPR

BitField.description:
Interrupt set-pending bits.
 Write:
 0 = No effect.
 1 = Changes interrupt state to pending.
 Read:
 0 = Interrupt is not pending.
 1 = Interrupt is pending.
 Note: Writing 1 to the NVIC_ISPR bit corresponding to:
 An interrupt that is pending has no effect.
 A disabled interrupt sets the state of that interrupt to pending.
BitField.name: SETPEND

Register.description: Use the Interrupt Clear-Pending Register to clear pending interrupts and determine which interrupts are currently pending.
Register.name: NVIC_ICPR

BitField.description:
Interrupt clear-pending bits.
 Write:
 0 = No effect.
 1 = Removes pending state and interrupt.
 Read:
 0 = Interrupt is not pending.
 1 = Interrupt is pending.
BitField.name: CLRPEND

Register.description: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.\n Note: Writing 1 to an NVIC_ICPR bit does not affect the active state of the corresponding interrupt.\n These registers are only word-accessible
Register.name: NVIC_IPR0

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 3
BitField.name: IP_3

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 2
BitField.name: IP_2

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 1
BitField.name: IP_1

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 0
BitField.name: IP_0

Register.description: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.
Register.name: NVIC_IPR1

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 7
BitField.name: IP_7

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 6
BitField.name: IP_6

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 5
BitField.name: IP_5

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 4
BitField.name: IP_4

Register.description: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.
Register.name: NVIC_IPR2

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 11
BitField.name: IP_11

BitField.name: IP_8

Register.name: NVIC_IPR3

BitField.name: IP_12

Register.description: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.
Register.name: NVIC_IPR4

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 19
BitField.name: IP_19

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 18
BitField.name: IP_18

BitField.name: IP_17

BitField.name: IP_16

Register.description: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.
Register.name: NVIC_IPR5

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 23
BitField.name: IP_23

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 22
BitField.name: IP_22

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 21
BitField.name: IP_21

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 20
BitField.name: IP_20

Register.description: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.
Register.name: NVIC_IPR6

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 27
BitField.name: IP_27

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 26
BitField.name: IP_26

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 25
BitField.name: IP_25

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 24
BitField.name: IP_24

Register.description: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.
Register.name: NVIC_IPR7

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 31
BitField.name: IP_31

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 30
BitField.name: IP_30

BitField.description: Priority of interrupt 29
